subject: Re: American pronunciation
msgSnippet: A phoneme represents a range of sounds or a category of sounds recognized by a speech community.  The range of sounds recognized as a particular word varies
messageBody:
A phoneme represents a range of sounds or a category of sounds
recognized by a speech community. The range of sounds recognized as
a particular word varies from word to word.

One locates phonemes by finding at least one minimal pair. A pair
of words which will change meaning if one feature is allowed to
vary: e.g. The existance of pit/pet means that the short i and short
e are both English phonemes.

If one dictionary pronunciation guide will not work for two dialects
of English, then there may also be problems with a phonemic
notation. Pitman argued that his i/t/a notation was not a
pronunciation guide since each locale determined what constituted an
ey sound.

An Australian probably has no difficulty distinguishing DAY and DIE
but an American might confuse the two "strine pronunciations.



--- "Joe" <allegrox_2000@y...> wrote:
>
> Read did set standards for certain prefixes and suffixes, fully
expecting standards to develop for others. (His can be found in the
Quikscript Manual, by the way.)

SB: I presume the manual is in the file section.

The solution that's been proposed for Shavian is to define the
sounds of letters with sample words and to allow the writer to use
the letter as (s)he pronounces it in that particular word.

Since sound changes are fairly uniform throughout any dialect, this
should still represent the same phoneme. For example, we could say
that /E/ represents the vowel found in "day", and it will always be
used for that phoneme, no matter how you actually pronounce it.

SB: Would E indicate /aI/ in Oz-speak?

If your dialect says [F], you still write /E/, and you do it
consistently. Australians will just learn a different sound-sign
assignment and pronounce it their way unless they're speaking in a
different accent.


I'm reminded of an article on the value of morphemic spelling,
which you can find here:
http://www.spellingsociety.org/journals/j2/gregersen.html

SB: If you spell kids and boys with an s, then you are engaged in
morphemic spelling which says that the plural will be spelled <s> no
matter how it is pronounced. boyz = boys.

--Steve
